headline: Chicken and Rice Salad with Pine Nuts and Lemon

name: Chicken and Rice Salad with Pine Nuts and Lemon
recipeIngredient: 1/4 cup plus 1 tablespoon lemon juice (from about 2 lemons)

recipeInstructions.text: In a small frying pan, toast the pine nuts over moderately low heat, stirring frequently, until they are golden brown, about 5 minutes. Or toast the pine nuts in a 350° oven for about 8 minutes.
In a small glass or stainless-steel bowl, whisk together the lemon juice, 1 teaspoon salt, and 1/4 teaspoon pepper. Add the oil slowly, whisking.

Bring a large pot of salted water to a boil. Add the peas; cook until just barely tender, about 3 minutes. Using a slotted spoon or a strainer, transfer to a large bowl. Add the rice to the water and cook until tender, about 15 minutes. Drain, return to the pot, and cover to keep warm.

Meanwhile, in a large frying pan, bring 1/4 inch of water to a simmer over moderately high heat. Sprinkle the chicken with salt and pepper and add to the pan. Cover, reduce the heat, and simmer, turning once, until cooked through, about 12 minutes. Remove the chicken, let cool slightly, and then cut into approximately 1/2-inch chunks.
Add the pine nuts, rice, chicken, raisins, scallions, parsley, lemon zest, and dressing to the large bowl and stir gently to mix.

review.reviewBody: We tried this for the first time today. Delicious! I was afraid the dressing would be too acidic, but it definitely isn’t. Nicely balanced. Like most recipes, we did a few things different to suit our tastes. We don’t particularly like raisins in our savory dishes, so we eliminated. We used brown rice that we cooked separately (we limit white starches in our diet for better glycemic load). And we grilled the chicken the night before rather than boiling it as described in this recipe. If I could find fresh peas, I think I’d use those rather than frozen, but the frozen peas were good. I would recommend using a good quality extra virgin olive oil because the olive oil definitely adds to the overall flavor profile (in a great way) without making it oily.
Great salad. I used sunflower seeds and dried cherries and it was still good.
Love love love this recipe! I have made it a number of times for luncheons and everyone raves about it. It's light and tasty, and the lemon is a perfect seasoning. I recommend it highly!
I pre-cooked some white and brown rices, let them cool overnight, then assembled the salad this morning for lunch later. It's fresh and light, tastes good. I might add spinach later.
